::: {.callout-note title="Analysis should answer the right questions" appearance="simple" collapse=true icon=false}
<br>
Analysis is for the public good and in line with government policy and organisational objectives.  
:::

::: {.callout-note title="Using the right methods" appearance="simple" collapse=true icon=false}
<br>
Analysis uses appropriate inputs and methods to produce high quality results.  

Quality analysis needs to be repeatable, independent, grounded in reality, objective, have understood and managed uncertainty, and the results should address the initial question robustly ([RIGOUR](/guidance/12-RIGOUR.qmd)).  
:::

::: {.callout-note title="At the right time " appearance="simple" collapse=true icon=false}
<br>

Analysis is provided in time to be useful. This should not be at the expense of quality assurance.
:::

::: {.callout-note title="With the right level of quality assurance" appearance="simple" collapse=true icon=false}
<br>

Ongoing quality assurance is built in to processes. It is proportionate to the decision being made and the risks associated with the intended use of the analysis.  

:::

::: {.callout-note title="Following the right standards" appearance="simple" collapse=true icon=false}
<br>
Analysis is undertaken in line with legal and ethical obligations and any other relevant public service codes of conduct  
:::

::: {.callout-note title="Presented in the right way " appearance="simple" collapse=true icon=false}
<br>
Analysis supports effective decision-making and meets user needs through clearly presented, impartial, timely and accessible outputs. This includes clear communication of context, strengths, limitations and any quality and uncertainty issues.  
:::

::: {.callout-note title="So the right decisions are made" appearance="simple" collapse=true icon=false}
<br>

Good quality analysis can be trusted to support effective decision-making and meet user needs.  
:::
